entry.et: Middle English see, from Old English sǣ; akin to Old High German sē sea, Gothic saiws

def.dt: :a great body of salt water that covers much of the earth
:the waters of the earth as distinguished from the land and air
:a body of salt water of second rank more or less landlocked the Mediterranean sea
:ocean
:an inland body of water used especially for names of such bodies the Caspian Sea
:surface motion on a large body of water or its direction
:a large swell or wave often used in plural heavy seas
:the disturbance of the ocean or other body of water due to the wind
:something likened to the sea especially in vastness a sea of faces
:the seafaring life
:mare
:on the sea
:on a sea voyage
:lost bewildered
:to or on the open waters of the sea
:a drag typically of canvas thrown overboard to retard the drifting of a ship or seaplane and to keep its head to the wind
:any of numerous usually solitary anthozoan polyps (order Actiniaria) whose form, bright and varied colors, and cluster of tentacles superficially resemble a flower
:any of numerous marine bony fishes (family Serranidae) that are usually smaller and more active than the groupers
:a food and sport fish (Centropristis striata) of the Atlantic coast of the United States
:any of numerous croakers or drums including noted sport and food fishes
:hardtack 1
:bream 2a
:a cooling breeze blowing generally in the daytime inland from the sea
:the master especially of a merchant vessel
:a change brought about by the sea
:a marked change :transformation a sea change in public policy
:a sailor's storage chest for personal property
